title: Add make readmes to make generate
Performance testing for parallelized versions of Rust/Go/C++ account scraper
body:
Build Rust, Go and parallelized C++ versions of the very basic acctScrape code (here: https://github.com/Great-Hill-Corporation/trueblocks-core/tree/master/src/apps/acctScrape).

This very minimal code should do similar processing for each language (parallel) reading the data file and deciding if the given address appears in that file, and if it does, report the 'x' appearance records found there. The format of the binary file is provided below.

This code will not be production level code, so don't spend any time make it pretty or adding options. Once the performance is understood it will be incorporated into the much larger project and mostly re-written.

The performance test will be simple -- we will just run each of the 'go', 'rust' and 'c++' versions against the same folder (with maybe 1000 copies of the data file) using 'time':

  >  time rust_scanner
  >  time go_scanner
  >  time cpp_scanner

There's no need for elaborate options parsing, although the folder name can be a command line option.

The C++ and Go versions are already written and can be found in ./src/other/parallel/cpp in the develop branch.  The Go version needs to be updated to read the binary file. Add the rust versions in the same folder.

Make a PR to the repo when you're ready.

**Here's the file format definition:**

[TrueBlocks Index Digests - File Format.pdf](https://github.com/Great-Hill-Corporation/trueblocks-core/files/4150273/TrueBlocks.Index.Digests.-.File.Format.pdf)

title: acctExport: customizing export display string
body: We used to be able to put a file in the monitors folder that would allow us to customize the display string. I think this still works, but it isn't tested, and it isn't probably working as designed.

title: acctExport: --receipt test cases don't work
body: The `export_dao` test case for `acctExport` does not report any actual data (all entries are blank).

title: Malicious takeover of previously owned ENS names
body:
### Impact
A user who owns an ENS domain can set a "trapdoor", allowing them to transfer ownership to another user, and later regain ownership without the new owner's consent or awareness.

### Patches

A new ENS deployment is being rolled out that fixes this vulnerability in the ENS registry. The registry is newly deployed at [0x00000000000C2E074eC69A0dFb2997BA6C7d2e1e](https://etherscan.io/address/0x00000000000C2E074eC69A0dFb2997BA6C7d2e1e).

### Workarounds
Do not accept transfers of ENS domains from other users on the old registrar.

Check the [migration guide](https://docs.ens.domains/ens-migration/guide-for-dapp-developers) in our docs.

title: Metric: Complexity Index
body:
Complexity index of an address -- the average number of traces per transaction throughout its history

This is an interesting aspect of ecosystem accounting

title: Beaver Release Process
body:
For core:
- [x] update program data such as names, whenBlocks, ipfs hashes, and timestamps (and other columns?)
- [x] revisit all data formats cleaning up any write/no write decisions and make all formats consistent
- [x] bump version strings
- [x] rerun all tests
- [x] update README files
- [x] consider revisiting TODO comments
- [ ] move all unclosed issues to the next release

For other repos:
- [x] Update version strings
- [ ] Rerun tests
- [ ] move all unclosed issues to the next release

title: acctlib: Parse the error string produced by the revert call
body:
We should be able to easily parse error strings (in fact, if we parse trace `output` at all, we will easily parse the revert string. We probably have to check to see if the transaction's `receipt` (or the trace `result`) shows an error. See this EIP: https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/ eip-140 and this Stack Exchange question: https://ethereum.stackexchange.com/questions/61844/revert-reason-and-parity-trace.

Related to Great-Hill-Corporation/trueblocks-core#946

title: acctExport: Showing and hiding fields in JSON export from acctExport
body:
`trans_fmt` only affects the row-based output (txt or csv). The JSON output shows every field — except those fields described in the show / hide config items.

To control what appears in the JSON data, you can play around with the ‘show / hide’ fields. For example, if you did

`hide = CTransaction: to, from`

the to and from fields would be removed from the JSON output. If you did,

`hide = CTransaction: receipt`

the receipt field would be hidden, but if you did

`show = CTransaction: all`

after that in the same config file, every field (including some that are hidden by default) would be shown

You can use both show and hide (hide is processed first):

```
hide = CTransaction: all
show = CTransaction: receipt
```

to show only the receipt.

You can show and hide different things in the same line. Separate data structures from each other with a pipe ‘|’ and fields within a data structure with commas:

```
hide = CTransaction: from, to, input | CReciept: contractAddress
show = CTrace: all | CTraceAction: all, CTraceResult: none
```

‘none’ and ‘all’ have opposite effects for show and hide.

As is true of the row-based display, you can find the fields in the C++ code `../src/libs/etherlib/[ transaction | receipt | logentry | trace | traceaction | traceresult ].cpp`

This should all be part of some sort of documentation.

title: testing: Failing tests on pristine installs
body:
tests we expect to fail for a user running doTesting...

getBloom_cache / getBloom_force_01 (migrate problem)
etherprice tests
ethslurp tests (if no api key)
~getBalance / getTokenBalance (fails on non-archive nodes)~

document, consider separating tests into groups (i.e. slow, ~need_state~, need_tracing)

title: We don't index pre-compiles
body:
1. This should be documented.
2. Precompiles are addresses 0x000..0001 - 0x000..0008
3. Probably should remove up to 0x000...000f as well (anticipating future pre-compiles)
4. Parity bug related to 0x0000...00004 is hidden by not including pre-compile 0x0000...0004 (which is a good thing)
5. Pre-compiles can be a supplimental index.

title: Minimum required version of parity
body:
The blockscrape must run against at least version 

```
Parity Ethereum
  version Parity-Ethereum/v2.3.4-beta-0e95db11d-20190220/x86_64-macos/rustc1.32.0
Copyright 2015-2018 Parity Technologies (UK) Ltd.
License GPLv3+: GNU GPL version 3 or later <http://gnu.org/licenses/gpl.html>.
This is free software: you are free to change and redistribute it.
There is NO WARRANTY, to the extent permitted by law.

By Wood/Paronyan/Kotewicz/Drwięga/Volf
   Habermeier/Czaban/Greeff/Gotchac/Redmann
```

AND VERY IMPORTANTLY -- THE ENTIRE CHAIN MUST BE SYNCED WITH THAT VERSION.  UPGRADED DATA FROM PREVIOUS VERSIONS OF PARITY HAVE BAD DATA IN THOSE PARTS THAT WERE SYNCED PREVIOUSLY.

title: getLogs: too can be greatly expanded
body:
Check out the CMakeLists.txt file in ./src/tools/getLogs.

Our current tool expects per transaction requests for logs, but the RPC provides for block level, address level, and even topic level requests. We should support this as it would be beneficial for 'logs only' version of the index. Related: Great-Hill-Corporation/trueblocks-core#1166

title: Document the way pre-funds work
body:
We build a single index file for block zero that has the same format as a regular index file but assigns fake transaction indexes to the pre-fund accounts. Rule to make the file:

1. Get a list of all prefund accounts and their balances:
     `addr\tbal_in_wei`
2. Sort the list by address
3. Add transactions to block zero with `blockNumber = 0` and `transactionIndex = row` where `row` is a zero-based index into the sorted list.

We need to do this because when we do `chifra export` we need to export the prefund transactions as if they were regular transactions so we can find them. A pre-fund transaction has a 'to' address of the account, a 'from' address of '0x0', a 'value' of the amount of ether the account was assigned at block zero, and a timestamp of block zero.

title: getTokenInfo: Add --info option
body:
The `getTokenBal` tool should accept additional parameters. For example, it should be able to return the `name`, `tokenSupply`, `symbol`, etc.

This can be done easily using existing code that retrieves a token's balance given an address. In fact, any 'const' function in an ABI can be queried using this method. See the code for getting token balances.

The correct four-byte codes are available from `grabABI` (but more easily through calling into the code that encodes function signatures).

title: acctScrape: Monitoring smart contracts
body:
Nice list of things to test for in a token contract:  https://ethresear.ch/t/token-contract-test-cases/1075

I can use this for the "Live Monitoring of Token Contracts in Real Time" idea.  The below are the functions which are to be checked. And I am guessing these are some of the test cases to check my contract. If there are more, or if there are any other functions to be added into the token also, please let me know.

- Approve (Approving allowance)
  - From owner account
  - From non-owner account
  - From a owner account after ownership
- transfer
  - Transfer From (Tranferring fund from an approved allowanced wallet)
  - Try the minimum amount
  - Try the maximum amount
  - Try any amount
  - Try an amount more than the range
  - Try an amount more than the token supply
  - Unpause (Unpause all the paused wallets together)
  - Transfer any amount
  - Mint (Mint new tokens)
  - Mint new tokens from owner
  - Mint new tokens from non-owner
  - Mint new tokens from owner after ownership transfer
  - Decrease Approval (Decrease already set approved allowance)
  - Decrease approval of a new wallet
  - Decrease approval of a earlier set wallet within range
  - Decrease approval of a earlier set wallet to zero
  - Decrease approval of a earlier set wallet taking just minimum amount
  - Decrease approval of a earlier set wallet greater than the current value
  - Finish Minting (Complete Minting Process for ever)
  - Try to mint again from owner account
  - Try to mint again from unknown account
  - Pause (Pause all wallets together) 
  - Try to transfer any amount
- Transfer
  - Transfer Minimum Amount
  - Transfer Maximum Amount
  - Tranfer Any Amount
  - Try an amount more than token supply
  - Transfer from an invalid account
- Approval
  - Increase Approval (Increase already set approved allowance)
  - Increase approval of a new wallet
  - Increase approval of a earlier set wallet within range
  - Increase approval of a earlier set wallet higher than token total supply
  - Increase approval of a earlier set wallet taking just minimum amount
  - Increase approval of a earlier set wallet lower than the current value
-Transfer Ownership (Transfer ownership to a new wallet)
  - Transfer ownership to a new account
  - Any help is appreciated.  
```

title: acctScrape: Design idea for acctScrape
body:
Eventually, `acctScrape` will pull its indexes from IPFS. In order to search the chain quickly, it must do this, but it doesn't have to pin those files. Only when `acctExport` exports a particular address's full transactional data should that index file be pinned.

In this way, each user will only ever pin the index he/she used and also heavily used smart contracts will pin nearly all the indexes (at least all those since it first started up).

The EF and/or Infura can pin all the files all the time so they are always available somewhere, and even in the worst case, the files can be re-generated.

title: etherlib: Additional options (--weekly, --daily, etc.) for block range parameters
body:
The `getBalance` command should have a new set of options:

- --period [five|hourly|daily|weekly|monthly|annually|nblocks]
- alternatively --weekly, --monthly, --yearly, --quarterly
- (or better yet enhance the block range parse code so it works for any tool)

We can use code from the `whenBlock` as the method by which to determine the most recent block number prior to the first second of the period.

For example, if `--weekly` is chosen, then the most recent block prior to the `startBlock` is Sunday morning midnight. Then, it should step through each Sunday morning midnight after that prior to `endBlock`. The code that generates the list of blocks to report on should first snap back to the start and then report  until the end of the range.

The best solution would alter the code in CBlockOptions class to allow for this option (although it could be that the command line interface is as above, while underneath, it could use this ability). This would allow the enhancement to benefit every tool that takes a block range. Possible examples:

```
getBalance <address> 5000000-6000000:weekly
getBalance <address> --weekly 5000000-6000000
whenBlock 0-latest:daily
```
If we add options such as --weekly, --daily, etc. these options should be available to all tools so this would be a change at the library level.

title: ethNames: Can we extend ethNames to use ENS in some way?
etherlib: Different chains
body:
If we wanted to handle different chains

net_version
Returns the current network id.

Parameters
none

Returns
String - The current network id.

"1": Ethereum Mainnet
"2": Morden Testnet (deprecated)
"3": Ropsten Testnet
"4": Rinkeby Testnet
"42": Kovan Testnet
Example
// Request
curl -X POST --data '{"jsonrpc":"2.0","method":"net_version","params":[],"id":67}'

// Result
{
  "id":67,
  "jsonrpc": "2.0",
  "result": "3"
}

title: chifra: seed should check to see if ipfs daemon is running
body: Currently, if `ipfs daemon` is not runnning, `chifra seed` will run but report errors. It should refuse to run if `ipfs daemon` is not running.

title: Provably true data
body:
Thinking out loud.

One of the amazing things that has happened recently is the ‘chifra seed’ thing. It works astonishingly well for getting data from one place to the next.

The Electron App can be a ’share’ platform for sharing historical data from the chain for anyone to use in something like R.

For example, that difficulty data we created in Prague.
The blocks per week, accounts per day, etc. etc.

Any data that is ‘immutable’ and ’time ordered’ and ‘derived from the chain’ can be shared in a provably true way if we also share the source code that went in to create the data. How do we do that? We make a .gz file of the source code tree, do `ipfs add` and store that hash (or maybe that hash and the commit in GIT) as the first record in any data we create.

Flat Buffers is great because it lets me build a flat file that needs no parsing. What I like about it is it has an arbitrary header. We can store this ‘code hash’ in the header to prove how the data was derived, and the data is ‘provably true.’

Just thinking out loud. I’ll add this to an issue.

body:

title: Documentation: Document the known_abis files
body:
During the `make` any files found in `./src/other/install/known_abis` will be copied into a folder called `~/.quickBlocks/known_abis`. These are then read by `getTrans` and the monitor code to help articulate common functions such as wallets and token standard.

This behavior is not documented.

title: Documentation: README format
body: https://github.com/RichardLitt/standard-readme/blob/master/spec.md

title: Documentation: blockScrape: handling of dDos blocks is not clear
body:
I'm pretty sure the `blockScrape` app skips over the DDos blocks between `DevCon2` and `State Clear` (at least it used to).

This means that all transactions during that time period are not included in the bloom filters.

At one point, I tried to fix this with this command: `getBloom --start devcon2 --end stateclear --force` which isn't right, but it sort of worked. I should fix the `blockScrape` code. 

**An example:**
Allow `blockScrape` to run with no options on a clean install, quit after block 2,700,000 and enter this command:

```
bloomMan 0x6d343663e55f734781e278b2b41a36c99e0bac40 2627736 -v:3
```

It will tell you `false` (i.e. the address is not in the block).

Now run:

```
bloomMan --rewrite 2627736
```

then run the above command again. It will return `true. 

**Note:** This may no longer be true, so if above doesn't work, just close this issue.

title: Documentation: Document block scraping data pipeline
body:
Use scraper.py.

blockScrape is doing the useful work.

miniBlock enables the whenBlock index of date to block. Wants to remove miniBlock, but doesn't want to destroy whenBlock.

blockScrape is responsible for the finalized/not finalized control flow.

title: Documentation: ethNames search documentation is completely wrong
body:
The search now works as this:

```
ethName search1 search2 search3

if (search1 is empty or "*") all addresses match else addresses.contains(search1)
if (search2 is empty or "*") all names+symbols match else (names+symbol).contains(search2)
if (search3 is empty or "*") all descriptions match else description.contains(search3)
```

all three have to match

```
* * BNT      (finds bnt (case insensitive) in description)
BNT * *      (fails because addresses don't contain N or T)
* BNT *      (finds BNT in name or symbol of address)
0x1 * *      (finds all addresses starting with 0x1)
0x1 BNT *    (finds addresses with both 0x1 in address and BNT in name or symbol)
```
